awd_titl_txt: IRES: Track II: The Coastal Processes & Machine Learning Advanced Studies Institute
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastlines host population centers, infrastructure, diverse ecosystems, and provide valuable tourism and recreational opportunities. Coastal regions are also prone to hazards such as storms, sea level rise, and chronic erosion. There is a growing volume of data available to scientists who study coastal processes and the future dynamics of coastlines. A range of new tools and methods that can be used to extract knowledge and insight from these data, especially machine learning techniques. However these new methods are not typically part of the graduate curriculum for coastal scientists. This project is focused on developing an advanced studies institute (ASI) in Auckland, New Zealand to teach machine learning methods to 20 US graduate students studying coastal processes and coastal geomorphology. The ASI participants are the next generation of US coastal scientists, who will get jobs in industry, agency, and academic settings.

The ASI is taught by several scientists who focus on applying machine learning methods to coastal problems. The institute directly impacts 20 US graduate student participants, and provides a focused experience for them to develop machine learning skills in a coastal context. The ASI is designed to leverage resources that are unique to New Zealand, including multiple high-fidelity datasets. All course materials for the ASI will be built with open source software and stored in open repositories to facilitate use in other coastal teaching and learning settings beyond this ASI. A project evaluation will investigate the ASI learning goals (post-event and longitudinally). ASI outcomes and learning materials will be disseminated in print, online, and at scientific conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is a growing volume of open data available for scientists to study coastal processes. To deal with the growing quantity of available of data, there has been a flurry of activity developing tools and techniques to harness the data revolution, especially machine learning (ML) methods. Yet many advances in ML have not percolate into non-computer science graduate programs, specifically for coastal professionals. The main goal of our proposal is to develop and teach an advanced studies institute (ASI) to teach ML methods to advanced graduate students studying coastal processes and coastal geomorphology. 

The original goal of offering an advanced studies institute was not possible because of pandemic related travel restrictions and other confounding factors. However the project did produce many pieces of open software, open data to be used for machine learning, and open access scientific publications about the created software and data that will aid in the adoption of Machine Learning methods throughout the coastal sciences and earth sciences. Several virtual workshops were also given, and video recordings of these events can be used to guide scientists in the future when exploring the use of machine learning tools for coastal and earth science research questions. The open software and open datasets will contribute toward the efforts to develop standards and benchmarks to compare ML algorithm performance in coastal research going forward.
